stories.storyText:
[Code Name] Viviana
[Gender] Female
[Combat Experience] 8 Years
[Place of Birth] Leithanien
[Date of Birth] Jul 21
[Race] Elafia
[Height] 171cm
[Infection Status]
Medical tests have confirmed that no infection is present.

[Physical Strength] Standard
[Mobility] Excellent
[Physical Resilience] Standard
[Tactical Acumen] Standard
[Combat Skill] Excellent
[Originium Arts Assimilation] Outstanding

Viviana Droste, descendant of the House of Hochberg's Kurfürst of Sturmland, and formerly a popular competition knight in Kazimierz. At the recommendation of Nearl the Radiant Knight, she has registered as a collaborating operator with Rhodes Island.
Proficient in light and shadow-based Arts, she is skilled at fending off enemies on the battlefield. During her time aboard the landship, she will be providing us tactical and field operational support.

Imaging tests reveal clear, normal outlines of internal organs, and no abnormal shadows have been detected. Originium granules have not been detected in the circulatory system and there is no sign of infection. At this time, the operator is believed to be uninfected.

[Cell-Originium Assimilation] 0%
She has been taking very good care of her skin, and has no scars or injuries at all.

[Blood Originium-Crystal Density] 0.12u/L
Madam Droste rarely comes into contact with Originium.

A Logistics operator working at the Convalescent Garden once saw Viviana standing under the grape aisle.
She simply stood there.
Her hooded robe hid all of her actions. The operator was only able to see her antlered, snow-white silhouette from behind, not moving an inch.
'Maybe she's going through some kind of training. Best not to interrupt her.'
The operator thought, and left the grape aisle to fertilize the seedbeds further inside the greenhouse.
When the operator finished her work and was about to head back to rest, she entered the grape aisle to find Viviana still standing there. This time, she was facing her, and she noticed her hands clasped together, with her right thumb knocking the back of her left hand rhythmically. Aside from this, she wasn't moving at all. Leisurely, she simply stood there in the corridor.
Then she opened her eyes.
She pointed her finger at her antlers, and asked the operator if she could help her out.
It was only then that the operator noticed that her colleague, who had been motionless the whole time like a statue in a museum, had actually gotten her antlers caught in the grapevines and was unable to free herself.
She quickly grabbed a pair of pruning shears, and carefully cut the vines for Viviana. After the brief commotion, Viviana was freed.
......
After that, the two of them sat on a stone bench next to the grape aisle and had a short chat. Viviana was going to walk through the corridor to the flowerbeds on the other side to check on the marigolds' growth, only to find the grapevines had gotten tangled on her antlers as she was walking past. She tried to free herself at first, only to find herself getting more and more stuck as she struggled, eventually landing in that predicament.
The Logistics operator was about to ask her why she didn't seek help. After all, there were many operators in the Convalescent Garden. If she'd yelled, she wouldn't have had to suffer like that. But when she noticed Viviana describing the flora's fragrance so vividly and in such detail, as well as how she turned the automatic sprinkler's noise into a rhythm, she opted not to ask such a stupid question.
'For someone as poetic as her, perhaps a sudden, unexpected event like this was only a part of her art,' the Logistics operator thought to herself.
The chat did not go on very long. The Logistics operator had other tasks to attend to, but when they parted ways, Viviana gave her a grapevine crown, made from the same vines that were just cut. The operator had been looking at her eyes the whole time and didn't notice her making the crown at all.
Afterwards, Viviana walked through the grape aisle and disappeared among the Convalescent Garden's flowerbeds.

When she informed Młynar that a campaign knight swordstaff with the Nearls' crest had appeared in Kargereich, the two of them returned to Kazimierz and informed Margaret. The news undoubtedly affected the Nearls greatly. It implies that Margaret's parents and Młynar's brother and sister-in-law had left behind a tiny clue to their whereabouts. Viviana has a deep understanding of the dangers of Kargereich. Not to mention that the Nearl family does not currently have the slightest clue how to reenter that strange unreality, and with Margaret still occupied with helping the Infected of Kazimierz, it would perhaps be a long time before they could investigate...
So Viviana promised Margaret that she would provide all the help she could. At the same time, she also sought her advice regarding her future. Although she had returned to Kazimierz, that did not mean she would once again become a competition knight—she had long since tired of that status. Although her foster mother, Rossi the Grand Knight, had lunch with her on the day of her arrival and expressed her concern, she was unable to find Viviana a place to go. Returning to Leithanien was also not an option in the short term. After she pondered this over and over, Viviana was even prepared to return to Ognisko to continue her pastoral lifestyle.
However, Margaret was able to read the hint of helplessness in her words and knew that her friend would not be satisfied with simply living a quiet life. Hiding deep within her heart there was a desire to help those around her, however possible. But because of her experiences and perspective, she had yet to find her way. Margaret was naturally more than happy to help with this. As such, she recommended Rhodes Island—Not its Kazimierzian offices, but Rhodes Island itself.
Viviana had heard a few things about what they had done in Kazimierz: They led a well-trained team of operators to help the Infected and dealt with all the corporations of the General Chamber of Commerce. This rather piqued her interest, and as she listened to Margaret's descriptions, she noticed something even more special about them she found attractive: Rhodes Island could provide her the opportunity to go somewhere far away from both Leithanien and Kazimierz, where she could once again seek out poetry and stories. And when Margaret told her about the time she faced Reunion in Chernobog and mentioned the Doctor and Amiya, the smile in the corner of her mouth and her unusually resolute eyes both got Viviana very curious. The changes Margaret went through from the time she quietly left Kazimierz after winning the championship, to her return to the Grand Knight Territory and taking the crown once more—before subsequently settling down—must have all been thanks to her time with Rhodes Island. What exactly was this island like, for the Radiant Knight, as impetuous yet unadaptable as she is, to become someone able to withstand the pressure of the GCC and stay in the Grand Knight Territory? What kind of place could earn such trust and loyalty from the knight she so admires? What kind of bewitching powers does the leader known as the 'Doctor' possess? She wanted to see it all with her own eyes.
And so, a few weeks later, Viviana arrived on Rhodes Island.

There was a power outage in the library, and the room fell into darkness. Although the administrator tried to raise his voice to calm the operators reading there, he was unable to quell the circulating complaints. Naturally, Viviana was already used to this kind of darkness. She took out her sword, placed it by the table, and used her Arts to light up a candle on her sword to continue reading the epic she had borrowed. Ever since she was small child, this was how she would always read. A small candle is more than enough to completely dispel an entire swath of darkness. When she was young, she relied on the light of a candle to read her books. There was much that she was unable to do in darkness, and perhaps the only resistance she could put up was to light a candle.
......
Viviana lifted her head to find a great number of operators gathered around her. They all wanted to keep reading, but none wanted to leave the library, and so they had gathered around this lonely light source. Viviana pondered a little, and used her Arts to light up the candle on the other end of her sword. Immediately, the long table she occupied was enveloped by a warm glow. The operators around her all expressed their gratitude, and she simply nodded and continued reading. Before, in the arenas, her candlelight was much more radiant than it now was. It was able to outshine the flashes of the cameras and the spotlights of the arena. Men gushed after her like surging tides as they yelled her title. Everyone had smiles on their faces, carefully choosing the words they showered her with, yet in their hearts—and Viviana knew this better than anyone—they were all trying to extract value from her. There were flames of greed burning in the eyes of her colleagues in the Nova Knightclub, and there were flames of fervor burning in the eyes of her fans. It was the light of these flames that lit the Grand Knight Territory. Her candlelight was but a part of this light, and this light of sickness was exhausting to her. And so she extinguished her own candlelight and walked into the darkness.
......
They huddled around the tableside candlelight and continued reading for a good while. The administrator then walked in and pointed out that the power had been restored, and they had to flip the switch in the breaker box back on, but as it would be very difficult to work alone in the dark, he asked if Viviana would be willing to help guide the way. Viviana kept her sword by the tableside, and lit her own candle holder. The faint flame brought with it an enormously bright glow that lit the library up like daylight. The administrator walked ahead of her, as she followed with her candle held high. As she looked on at the silhouette that straddled between darkness and light, she couldn't help but think back on what she had endured in Kargereich. There had been no one to guide her. She could only raise the candle in her hand by herself and attempt to find something in that darkness. She walked past countless herselves, each with a candlelight that lit, only to go out. In the end, all that was left was— The administrator reached the breaker box, and he signaled to her that she may now put her candle away. Thus, she waved her hand. The flames on the candle holder and her sword all extinguished at once, and a darkness befell the space around them. Emptiness, hollowness, and the freezing cold. These were once the things she was most afraid of. But she had gotten through all of them. The ice-cold darkness of her childhood was unable to defeat her, nor the hollow darkness of Kargereich after she had grown up. Is it because she is the light that illuminates the dark, or is it because she is the darkness itself?
The lights of the library slowly lit up, and everything returned to normal. Viviana returned to her table, picked up her book, and continued reading.

In that dream of Kargereich, Viviana saw her younger self. She saw her many mistakes and regrets. Many past events have faded as time went on, and can never again be recovered, but there are a few insignificant bits and pieces that can still be retrieved from the corners of her memory. There are still certain childish parts to her adult self. In the past, because of her constraints and to stay out of the reporters' sight, she could only keep those urges hidden deep in her heart, but now...
'Um... Er...' Nearl the Radiant Knight did not have the words to express everything going through her mind when she saw the dream-like palace built of a variety of dolls in the corner of the dormitory. On the other hand, the master of the palace welcomed her dumbfounded guest with a smile that embodied her satisfaction and joy.
It was no surprise that the knight was so flabbergasted. In that realm, there was a green patch of grass and a lake painted onto the carpet. The half-open cabinets in the corner of the wall formed a mountain range and a castle. There was a warm, gentle glow emanating from the light hanging above, with everything surrounded on all sides by dust covers.
Wild, woolen beasts of all kinds fed on the ground, paying no heed to the humans toiling nearby. The tin sentinels held their long spears tight in their hands. The silver princess ran barefoot in the field of grass.
The knight was about to say something, only for the master of this tiny realm to press a button and the castle in the cabinet began to change shape, revealing even more eccentric scenes: the Gesatzswächter trimming vines with a pair of shears in his hands, the blindfolded lady playing a foreign instrument with ease, the poet embracing his wife and lounging on a chair, and a finely-crafted model of what appeared to be a sword or a spear laid sound asleep in the wool by their feet...
Still unable to recover from her shock, the knight thought carefully about the pile of dolls. Especially the woolen one with the Nearl family crest in the corner. Aside from giving her old friend an embarrassed smile, the knight could not think of what else to do...
This sudden, minor farce did not last for long. After a simple round of teasing, the knight obtained the records she had wanted from her friend: inside were the complete sequence of events Viviana had compiled from her recollections. With all the matters she had to attend to dealt with, the two's meeting aboard Rhodes Island came to a close for the time being. Before she departed though, Margaret suddenly had a question. She had seen herself among the puppets, yet their master herself was nowhere to be seen among them.
The master did not give her an answer. She simply smiled and flipped another switch. The 'sun' slowly turned and revealed the secret hidden inside—
A young 'Master' slept curled up within, but her two antlers were already interwoven with light, illuminating the entire room.

[Private Permissions - Doctor]
......

[Special Parcel Report]
Recipient: Viviana Droste
Sender: Unknown, but judging from the Goldmond greatsword golden wax seal, it was likely to be a Leithanian Gesatzswächter
Parcel contents: Originium Arts detection showed an oil painting of a small alley in Zwillingstürme. The parts of the oil painting depicting plants contained numerous real marigold seeds.
Processing suggestions: The oil painting contains no Originium Arts, the flower species is not blacklisted, the sender's identity may be ignored, process normally
......
Subsequent report: Verification has identified sender Gesatzswächter Brandt Reiner as a close friend of the recipient. After receipt, Operator Viviana hung the painting on the wall of her room. The marigold seeds were planted in a pot and will soon bloom. No further attention required.
......
[This report has been archived and declassified]

skins.description:
An outfit commonly worn by Operators.
While not as practical as a uniform, it's what they find most comfortable.

An outfit that has been improved after the Operator's Promotion.
Custom-made to suit each Operator's experiences and needs, these outfits are designed to provide them maximum flexibility on any battlefield. Furthermore, this is all done without compromising the comfort that they've come to expect.

<$ba.charged>Charged</> effect: Attack range <@ba.vup>+2</>, and hits 3 times

ATK <@ba.vup>+{atk:0%}</>, DEF <@ba.vup>+{def:0%}</>, Block <@ba.vup>+{block_cnt}</>, and attacks all blocked enemies. Each attack has a <@ba.vup>{attack@prob_twice:0%}</> chance to be 2 hits with <@ba.vup>{attack@atk_scale_twice:0%}</> ATK and <$ba.steal>Steal</> <@ba.vup>{attack@steal_atk_speed}</> ASPD from the target (up to a total of {attack@steal_atk_speed_max}, lasts until skill expires or Viviana leaves the battlefield)

modules.desc:
Operator Viviana has demonstrated a remarkable aptitude for inflicting Arts damage on the enemy in close-quarters combat.
The Field Operations Department has thus passed the following resolution:
This operator shall be appointed a Guard Operator during field operations to exercise Arts Fighter responsibilities.
In witness whereof,
This badge is hereby conferred upon the above named.

Multiple people have opined to me at length about what they think of Nova Knightclub's 'plans', how my 'vacation' might signal the Knightclub's future decisions, and so on and so forth. Still, as the Grand Knight Territory and its ghastly white glowing metal walls faded beyond the horizon, all those speculations lost their meaning. In my mind, I was simply being sent to yet another place not of my choosing. The silver lining, at least, is that I don't hate it here. Every morning in Ognisko, all the workshops fire up their furnaces at almost the same time, and the blacksmiths all hail each other good morning over the clamor of fire and metal. It's an organic, living noise that pays no heed to what outsiders bring or take away. I took up assistant duties in an arms workshop to stave off the boredom. Orders are always coming in from Kawalerielki, with plenty of familiar names attached. Nova is now raising a 'Moonlight Knight' who uses a sword made of fluid alloy—I only later found out they swapped those red wine baths and handsome manservants for moonlight hammocks and silver-furred manglerbeast sidekicks. In contrast, the blacksmith at my workshop never asks which knight she's forging for, nor does she care who I am—be it the Candle Knight or a commoner—and isn't concerned whether her weapons go to competition knights or barren mercenaries. She never reads the 'knight persona' briefing attached to any of her orders. But she does care about her craft. Sometimes, I'll stop and admire the fire in the hearth, and she'll proudly recount the tale of how the first fire came from the heavens. It fell to the land in its divinity, and where it fell the land was blessed with metal, and thus the craft of smelting and forging was born. 'Shame,' she said once, 'that nobody believes any of it now.' I told her that when I was very young, I saw fire falling from the heavens. She listened, and then she laughed, sensing how cursory my words were, how I was trying to save her from embarrassment. Changing the subject, she asked if I'd like to raise the ceiling's workshop a little, so I wouldn't have to walk everywhere stooped over. I declined, and she said no more. As if by coincidence, on my second day, a radio program came on with an astronomical report, forecasting a meteor over Ognisko. After all the furnaces in town went out that night, the blacksmith and I stood by the workshop door, and saw blue ripples across the sky. According to an old folksong, those are made as the meteors stir the starpod, though this meteor remained hidden behind the hills. The blacksmith's eyes were all aglow. Her feet set in motion, as if to chase that blazing light. After running some distance, she turned to look back at me. 'Aren't you coming?' 'I'm fine watching from here. The ripples its tail leaves in the sky are beautiful, too.' I did lie, in a way, when I told her I'd seen fire falling to the ground as a child. It was true a meteor crossed Sturmland's skies, but only the window on the wrong side was opened in my room. I didn't want to wake Father and beg him to take me outside. I never saw a meteor that evening, and so instead I clutched my ice-cold binoculars and told myself, 'It's fine. The ripples its tail leaves in the sky are beautiful, too.' And no, I was never in denial about just how achingly stunning the blazing glint of the meteor itself could be. I just never spoke of it. Just as every time I light a candle, I see only the shadow beneath it. The blacksmith vanished into the night. I looked all around, and saw the burdenbeast tethered by the workshop door. In all the knight novels, Kuranta knights could cross entire prairies on their own two feet, never in need of a steed. But I am no Kuranta, and right now, no knight either—This thought crossed my mind as I mounted the burdenbeast and rode off, chasing where the meteor had vanished.

talents.name: Candlelight

voice_lines.voiceText: Hm, by the way, may I ask who was your previous assistant? No, I'm not snooping or anything. It's just... There's not much I can do for you here, besides offer my quiet thoughts on the occasional poem.

I see what you're hiding behind your back. Be at ease, I know very well that Leithanien needs a citizen to heighten her glory in foreign lands. Kazimierz, on the other hand, needs a scandal-plagued knight of self-professed purity. Both are as plain as day. Besides, that issue of The Red Wine is outdated. Their kinds never run short of personalities to gossip over.

The wind can get very strong up on the decks. Perhaps you should change into something warmer. Me? I'm just dressing this place up as a certain city of greenery and shade in my imagination. The one where the gentle breeze blew from lands unknown, and the blacksmith's rhythmic hammering sounded the passage of time... Those days were brief. So brief, they are worth remembering.

'Droste' is my mother's maiden name. It is a common name with no place in the spires. How long would you stay in an alley full of marigolds, Doktor? Very few would grace their proses and stanzas with these forbidden blossoms, but they're really beautiful... To be honest, I'm surprised you actually remembered my full name, Doktor.

Poetry is charming as a respite from grammatical convention. It is a search for the most fitting of expressions in the most irrational.  The Candle Knight, who upholds virtue, and Viviana, who loves poetry... I have been a contradiction since the very beginning.

Tales about foreign lands usually end with the traveler returning home. I was always preparing to return to Leithanien, but even after having experienced so much, my truest imp ression of the place remains in the candlelit books on those dark nights. I've seen the people I wanted to see, and I've made my choice.

Look. What is it the candle lights here? Our faces? Lines of poetry that no one reads? Or the dark and mired path ahead of us? I guess you've always been able to see them, even without my candlelight. Right then, rest your eyes upon me. Don't let the light distract your gaze.

I returned to that small, dark chamber in the spire and spoke to the little girl within. I told her that she will endure a lifetime of slander, suffer regrets that cannot be undone, and be trapped in a cycle of endless pursuit and loss… Yes, farewells feel the same as a dream. Do you find me, as I am in this moment, real enough?

'If you and I were notes from one stanza, on which instrument are we strung? And what player has us in his hand?' Oh, I knew you would come. Have you finished reading the poems I gave you? Let me guess. I couldn't possibly share the image of your beloved, and it must lie within the most uplifting cantata.
Mein Tag war heiter, glücklich meine Nacht.
Greetings. Margaret told me about you.  It's a shame we didn't have a chance to meet in the Grand Knight Territory… They called me 'The Candle Knight' at the time. You can call me Viviana, Doktor.
Watching my own fights through a screen... For a moment, I thought I was still in Kazimierz.
Are you going to grant me a title as well? There's no need for that, but it probably won't matter anyway. This place is no arena.
Can I interpret this as... your hope that I will stay?
I, Viviana Droste, shall wield candle and blade to win victories in your name.
Um, truth be told, the General Chamber of Commerce's spokesmen kept complaining that I didn't care much about my own matches.
Let us move. A timely departure paves the way for an early return.
Moonlight barely laid upon the breezy parterre, yet you've witnessed the entirety of autumn?
I listen, to this passing silence.
I wait, for that belated serenity.
This is no arena. No scars will be remembered or awarded.
Leave. This is my last suggestion.
Why obsess over rhymes? Poetry is woven with the thread of ideas.
'Pale roses,' pale minds.
Alas, but tying your legs together won't make you fly.
Let time rest upon this unlit night.
Tired already, Doktor? Me too. The last time I had such an unforgettable bout was that match I fought in Kawalerielki.
Doktor, you're right. Words that shake one's soul always come from within the storm.
Even the most uninspiring poetry may contain a few lines that tug at our hearts. Despite the regrettable techniques employed, I can't help but approve of the writer's expression.
Doktor, accept this temporary lapse in creativity and remember how this moment feels. I'm still looking forward to the completion of this sonnet.
No bathtub...? Never mind. Just a little joke.
Hmm, who is there? Whatever. I already knew it was you.
Doktor, if the candle goes out, I can't say for sure what might happen next.
Arknights.

Every year, my father spent the New Year with the nobles of the territory, and everyone who lived nearby were given their rewards. That was when I could finally speak loudly in my room. No one was ever there to notice me, and I paid no mind to the boisterousness outside, either... I was still young, but I still remember.
Hmm, Doktor, what are you muttering there? I won't force you to recite any poems. But you have read them, have you not?

Come read with me, Doctor. Ever since I came here, I've rarely found myself so agitated that I couldn't read. Oh, right. If you find any books that interest you, please feel free to take them when you leave, even though you gave me plenty of them... Happy birthday, Doctor.

People often say that the era we live in has no need for poetry. They claim it cannot provide leisure, and it is loathed for certain men's pretentious elegance. But there is someone who once proved to me the value of 'reminders.' In that case, I wish to walk with you to remind this era, with a candle, and a poem.

building_skills.desc: When this Operator is assigned to the Control Center, increases Morale of all Operators in the Control Center by <@cc.vup>+0.05</> per hour.
When this Operator is assigned to the Control Center, all <$cc.tag.knight><@cc.kw>Knight</></> Operators assigned to Factories gain productivity <@cc.vup>+7%</>
